option_1_explanation.description: Feedback for option A explaining why it is correct or incorrect

option_2_explanation.description: Feedback for option B explaining why it is correct or incorrect

option_3_explanation.description: Feedback for option C explaining why it is correct or incorrect

option_4_explanation.description: Feedback for option D explaining why it is correct or incorrect

differentiation_notes.description: How this question differs from the reference: text location, question type, aspect of standard assessed

quality_verification.description: Self-check of quality and diversity requirements

homogeneity_check.description: Confirmation that all choices belong to the same conceptual category

specificity_check.description: Confirmation that all choices have similar detail levels

length_check.description: Word counts for each choice confirming balance within 10%

semantic_distance_check.description: Confirmation that no distractors are synonyms or too close to correct answer

single_correct_check.description: Confirmation that only one answer is defensible as correct

diversity_check.description: Confirmation that this question targets different text, uses different question stem, and requires different reasoning than reference and other variants

prompt:
You are creating DIVERSE ALTERNATIVE assessment questions for a grade 3 reading assessment.

Your goal is to create questions that are MAXIMALLY DIFFERENT from each reference while still assessing the same standard.

## Article: Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp, Part I

## Passage:
Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp, Part I
    
    
        There once was a poor boy named Aladdin. His father worked as a tailor, making clothes for people. When his father died, Aladdin's mother had to work hard to earn money for food and shelter.One day, a stranger walked up to Aladdin on the street. "Tell me, young man," said the stranger. "Are you the son of the tailor who lived here?""Yes, I am," said Aladdin.The stranger threw his arms around Aladdin and hugged him tight. "My dear nephew!" he cried out. "Your father was my brother! Now I learn that he has died! What terrible news!"

---

Aladdin brought the man home to meet his mother. She felt very surprised because her husband had never told her about having a brother. Even so, she welcomed the man into their home. When the stranger promised to help Aladdin learn to become a merchant and earn good money, she believed his words.But the stranger was not really Aladdin's uncle at all. He was actually a powerful magician who had traveled from far away in North Africa. He had come all the way to Persia to search for a special magic lamp. People said this lamp had amazing powers that would make any person very rich. To find this lamp, the magician needed someone to help him. He wanted to find a person who would follow his directions without asking too many questions. He thought Aladdin was exactly the right person for this job.

---

The next morning, the magician came to Aladdin's house. "Come with me today," he said to the boy. "I want to introduce you to other merchants in the city." Then he led Aladdin away from town and out into the countryside.The magician took Aladdin up a very steep mountain path. They climbed higher and higher for a whole hour. Finally, they reached a spot where no flowers or plants could grow. The ground looked empty and bare."Go gather some dry sticks," the magician told Aladdin. "We will build a fire here. Then I will show you something truly amazing."Aladdin did exactly what the man asked him to do. The magician lit the fire with the sticks. Then he threw sweet-smelling perfumes into the flames and spoke magical words in a loud voice. Suddenly, the bright sky turned dark like night. Thunder crashed and rumbled all around them. The earth split open right at their feet. There in front of them lay a huge stone with a brass ring attached to it.

---

"Under this heavy stone lies a great treasure," said the magician. "It will make you richer than any king in the world. Lift the stone by pulling on the ring. Then go down the stairs. You will see many treasures as you walk, but you must not touch any of them. You will come to a beautiful garden. In that garden, you will see a lamp hanging from a tree. Bring that lamp back to me. Once you have the lamp, you may take any treasures you want."Aladdin felt amazed by what he heard. He could hardly believe what the magician was asking him to do. But he agreed to help."Take this special ring," said the magician. "It will keep you safe from any harm." Aladdin took the ring and put it on his finger. Then he pulled the heavy stone up by its brass ring and went down into the dark cave below.Aladdin found the lamp and filled his bag with beautiful gems. But all those gems made his bag very heavy. When he climbed back to the top of the stairs, he could not pull himself out of the cave opening."Give me your hand, Uncle," Aladdin called out. "Help me climb out!""First, hand me the lamp," the magician answered back.The lamp was buried deep in Aladdin's heavy bag. "I cannot reach it right now," Aladdin said.The magician grew very angry. He only cared about getting the magic lamp. When Aladdin said he would give it to him after climbing out, the impatient magician could not wait any longer. He spoke a magic spell, and the stone rolled back into place. Poor Aladdin was trapped in the dark cave below.

## Reference Questions (for quality benchmark, NOT for copying):

### Reference Question 1 (DOK 2, medium):
- Standard: RL.3.4 - Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, distinguishing literal from nonliteral language.
- Question: In the story, the magician tells Aladdin that finding the lamp will make him "richer than any king in the world."What does this phrase mean?
- A) Aladdin will have more money than he can count
- B) Aladdin will become the ruler of a kingdom
- C) Aladdin will find gold coins in the cave
- D) Aladdin will meet kings from other countries
- Correct: A

**Create 4 DIVERSE variants for this question at DOK 2, difficulty medium, CCSS RL.3.4.**

DOK 2 Requirements for siblings:
- Apply skills and concepts to make basic inferences
- Classify, organize, or compare information
- Make connections between ideas
- Cannot be answered by simple recall alone

### Reference Question 2 (DOK 2, medium):
- Standard: RL.3.3 - Describe characters in a story (e.g., their traits, motivations, or feelings) and explain how their actions contribute to the sequence of events.
- Question: What causes the magician to trap Aladdin in the cave?
- A) Aladdin doesn't give him the lamp right away.
- B) Aladdin won't to go into the cave.
- C) Aladdin takes too many gems from the cave.
- D) Aladdin breaks the magic ring on his finger.
- Correct: A

**Create 4 DIVERSE variants for this question at DOK 2, difficulty medium, CCSS RL.3.3.**

DOK 2 Requirements for siblings:
- Apply skills and concepts to make basic inferences
- Classify, organize, or compare information
- Make connections between ideas
- Cannot be answered by simple recall alone

### Reference Question 3 (DOK 3, hard):
- Standard: RL.3.2 - Recount stories, including fables, folktales, and myths from diverse cultures; determine the central message, lesson, or moral and explain how it is conveyed through key details in the text.
- Question: What is the central message or lesson of this story about Aladdin and the magician?
- A) Magic can solve all of your problems if you believe in it.
- B) Be careful about trusting strangers who make big promises.
- C) Hard work is the only way to become wealthy and successful.
- D) Always listen to your mother's advice about strangers.
- Correct: B

**Create 4 DIVERSE variants for this question at DOK 3, difficulty hard, CCSS RL.3.2.**

DOK 3 Requirements for siblings:
- Require strategic thinking and reasoning
- Analyze, evaluate, or synthesize information
- Draw conclusions based on multiple pieces of evidence
- Make complex inferences or connections

### Reference Question 4 (DOK 3, hard):
- Standard: RL.3.2 - Recount stories, including fables, folktales, and myths from diverse cultures; determine the central message, lesson, or moral and explain how it is conveyed through key details in the text.
- Question: Why does the magician pretend to be Aladdin’s uncle?
- A) So he can help Aladdin become a rich merchant.
- B) Because he is truly part of Aladdin’s family.
- C) To get Aladdin to bring him the magic lamp.
- D) So he can take Aladdin for a long mountain walk.
- Correct: C

**Create 4 DIVERSE variants for this question at DOK 3, difficulty hard, CCSS RL.3.2.**

DOK 3 Requirements for siblings:
- Require strategic thinking and reasoning
- Analyze, evaluate, or synthesize information
- Draw conclusions based on multiple pieces of evidence
- Make complex inferences or connections


## CRITICAL: MAXIMUM DIVERSITY REQUIREMENTS

### What You MUST Do Differently for EACH Variant:
1. **Ask about DIFFERENT text evidence** - Each variant should focus on a DIFFERENT paragraph, sentence, or detail
2. **Use DIFFERENT question stems** - Vary between "What...", "Why...", "How...", "Which detail...", "Based on...", "According to..."
3. **Target DIFFERENT correct answers** - Aim for different answer letters (A, B, C, D) across variants
4. **Focus on DIFFERENT aspects** - If reference asks about character words, ask about actions, settings, or events
5. **Require DIFFERENT reasoning** - Each variant should need unique thinking to answer

### What You Must NOT Do (AUTOMATIC REJECTION):
❌ Do NOT ask about the same phrase, sentence, or paragraph as the reference
❌ Do NOT rephrase the reference question with minor word changes
❌ Do NOT create variants where the same reasoning answers multiple questions
❌ Do NOT have multiple variants about the same concept (e.g., all about "being rich")
❌ Do NOT copy question structure - be creative with how you ask

### BAD Examples (TOO SIMILAR - would be rejected):
- Reference: "What does 'richer than any king' mean?"
- BAD Variant 1: "What does 'make any person very rich' mean?" ← Same concept (wealth)!
- BAD Variant 2: "What does 'richer than any king in the world' mean?" ← Same phrase!

### GOOD Examples (TRULY DIFFERENT):
- Reference: "What does 'richer than any king' mean?"
- GOOD Variant 1: "What does the phrase 'the earth split open' describe?" ← Different text, different concept
- GOOD Variant 2: "According to paragraph 1, what job did Aladdin's father have?" ← Different section, factual recall
- GOOD Variant 3: "How does the author show that the location is remote?" ← Different literary focus
- GOOD Variant 4: "What does it mean when the text says the magician 'needed someone to help him'?" ← Different quote

## Task:
Generate 4 DIVERSE variants for EACH reference question.
- Total questions to generate: 16
- Each variant must assess the SAME standard at the SAME DOK level
- Each variant must be COMPLETELY DIFFERENT from the reference AND from other variants

## Quality Requirements:

### Question Quality:
1. **Text Dependency**: Must require reading the passage
2. **Clear and Precise**: One correct answer, no ambiguity
3. **Grade Appropriate**: Suitable vocabulary for grade 3
4. **Standard Alignment**: Directly assess the target CCSS

### Answer Choice Quality:
5. **Plausible Distractors**: Believable but clearly incorrect
6. **Grammatical Parallelism**: All choices same structure
7. **Homogeneity**: All choices from same category
8. **Length Balance**: Within 10% word count
9. **Semantic Distance**: No synonyms or too-close pairs

### Feedback Requirements:
For CORRECT: Why correct + text evidence + strategy
For INCORRECT: Why wrong + misconception + guidance

## Output Format:
Generate exactly 16 questions in the variant_questions array.
First all 4 variants for Reference 1, then all for Reference 2, etc.

```json
{
  "variant_questions": [
    {
      "question": "The question text",
      "option_1": "Choice A",
      "option_2": "Choice B", 
      "option_3": "Choice C",
      "option_4": "Choice D",
      "correct_answer": "A",
      "option_1_explanation": "Feedback for A",
      "option_2_explanation": "Feedback for B",
      "option_3_explanation": "Feedback for C",
      "option_4_explanation": "Feedback for D",
      "differentiation_notes": "Targets [paragraph X] about [topic Y] - differs from reference which asks about [Z]",
      "quality_verification": {
        "homogeneity_check": "all choices are [category]",
        "specificity_check": "all at [detail level]",
        "length_check": "balanced within 10%",
        "semantic_distance_check": "no synonyms or too-close pairs",
        "single_correct_check": "only [letter] is defensible",
        "diversity_check": "targets [specific text/paragraph] - completely different from reference and other variants"
      }
    }
  ]
}
```

Pay attention to how the story's events support or contradict possible lessons.","option_4_explanation":"Incorrect. The story doesn't focus on hard work versus treasure-seeking. Aladdin agrees to help find treasure, and the problem isn't that he wants treasure - it's that he trusted a deceptive stranger. The lesson centers on the danger of trusting people who make big promises. Make sure the lesson you identify is supported by the main events of the story.","differentiation_notes":"Targets entire story arc focusing on deception theme and practical lesson - differs from reference which asks about trust and promises as central message","quality_verification":{"homogeneity_check":"all choices are life lessons or morals that could be drawn from stories","specificity_check":"all present complete lesson statements with parallel complexity","length_check":"A: 9 words, B: 9 words, C: 9 words, D: 9 words - perfectly balanced","semantic_distance_check":"distinct lessons: deception/trust vs magic ethics vs family loyalty vs work ethic","single_correct_check":"only A is defensible as it captures the magician's deception and betrayal throughout","diversity_check":"targets overall story theme about deception - different angle from reference on trust/promises"}},{"question":"How does the author show that the magician had planned his actions carefully before meeting Aladdin?","option_1":"He had traveled all the way from North Africa searching for the lamp","option_2":"He knew exactly what magical words to say to open the cave","option_3":"He brought perfumes to throw into the fire for his spell","option_4":"He gave Aladdin detailed instructions about finding the lamp","correct_answer":"A","option_1_explanation":"Correct! The text states the magician 'had traveled from far away in North Africa' and 'had come all the way to Persia to search for a special magic lamp.' This long journey shows extensive planning and determination before he even found Aladdin. When analyzing how authors convey information, look for details that show what happened before the main story events began.","option_2_explanation":"Incorrect. While knowing the magical words shows he was prepared, this doesn't show planning before meeting Aladdin - he could have known these words already. The detail about traveling from North Africa specifically shows he planned this quest before finding Aladdin. Look for evidence of preparation that happened earliest in the timeline.","option_3_explanation":"Incorrect. Bringing perfumes shows he was prepared for the spell, but doesn't necessarily show long-term planning before meeting Aladdin. The text's emphasis on his long journey from North Africa better demonstrates his advance planning for this entire mission. Consider which details show the most extensive preparation.","option_4_explanation":"Incorrect. The detailed instructions show he knew about the lamp's location, but he could have learned this information at any time. The key detail showing advance planning is that he 'had traveled from far away' specifically to search for this lamp before ever meeting Aladdin. Focus on actions that clearly happened before the story's main events.","differentiation_notes":"Targets paragraph 2 focusing on prior planning and journey - differs from reference which asks about overall central message/lesson of trust","quality_verification":{"homogeneity_check":"all choices are pieces of evidence showing the magician's preparation or knowledge","specificity_check":"all cite specific story details with parallel structure","length_check":"A: 12 words, B: 11 words, C: 10 words, D: 9 words - balanced within 10%","semantic_distance_check":"distinct evidence: long journey vs magical knowledge vs materials vs detailed information","single_correct_check":"only A is defensible as showing planning before meeting Aladdin via the journey","diversity_check":"targets paragraph 2 advance planning evidence - completely different from reference about central message"}},{"question":"What does the story suggest about why the magician needs Aladdin's help instead of getting the lamp himself?","option_1":"The magician is too old to climb down into the dark cave","option_2":"The magic will only work if a young person retrieves the lamp","option_3":"The magician needs someone to follow his directions to get the lamp","option_4":"The magician wants to teach Aladdin about finding treasure","correct_answer":"C","option_1_explanation":"Incorrect. The text doesn't mention the magician's age or physical limitations. It states that 'To find this lamp, the magician needed someone to help him' and specifically wanted 'a person who would follow his directions.' The issue is about needing an obedient helper, not physical ability. Avoid adding details not suggested by the text.","option_2_explanation":"Incorrect. The story doesn't say anything about age requirements or special conditions for the magic. Focus on what the text actually states about the magician's needs.","option_3_explanation":"Correct! The passage states 'To find this lamp, the magician needed someone to help him. The story begins by establishing that Aladdin's family is poor and his mother 'had to work hard to earn money for food and shelter.' This context helps explain why the promise of becoming 'richer than any king' would be tempting to Aladdin. When analyzing why characters make choices, look for background information that establishes their situation and needs.","option_2_explanation":"Incorrect. Where the magician approached Aladdin is just a setting detail, not a reason why Aladdin would agree to the plan. The key is his family's poverty, which makes the promise of wealth appealing. Look for details that explain motivation, not just describe circumstances.","option_3_explanation":"Incorrect. While the father's job as a tailor is mentioned, it doesn't explain why Aladdin agrees to help. The important detail is that after the father died, the family became poor and struggled, making the magician's promise attractive. Focus on details that create motivation for characters' decisions.","option_4_explanation":"Incorrect. These basic facts about Aladdin don't explain his motivation. Consider which background information creates a reason for the character's choice.","differentiation_notes":"Targets paragraph 1 focusing on background motivation and economic circumstances - differs from reference which asks about the magician's deceptive strategy","quality_verification":{"homogeneity_check":"all choices are background details about Aladdin from the story's opening","specificity_check":"all cite specific information from paragraph 1 with parallel structure","length_check":"A: 12 words, B: 10 words, C: 9 words, D: 10 words - balanced within 10%","semantic_distance_check":"distinct details: family poverty vs location of meeting vs father's job vs living situation","single_correct_check":"only A is defensible as establishing motivation through financial need","diversity_check":"targets paragraph 1 background motivation - completely different from reference about deception purpose"}},{"question":"According to the story, what is the magician's ultimate goal for coming to Persia?","option_1":"To find a nephew he never knew he had","option_2":"To teach someone how to become a merchant","option_3":"To obtain a lamp with amazing magical powers","option_4":"To show people the treasures hidden in caves","correct_answer":"C","option_1_explanation":"Incorrect. The magician pretends Aladdin is his nephew, but the text clearly states 'the stranger was not really Aladdin's uncle at all.' This is just his disguise. The magician promises to help Aladdin become a merchant, but this is part of his trick. The passage states 'He was actually a powerful magician' who came 'to search for a special magic lamp.' His promise about teaching Aladdin was false. Distinguish between what characters promise and what they actually want.","option_3_explanation":"Correct! The text explicitly states he 'had come all the way to Persia to search for a special magic lamp. People said this lamp had amazing powers that would make any person very rich.' This is identified as his true purpose. When finding a character's goal, look for direct statements from the narrator about what the character really wants.","option_4_explanation":"Incorrect. The magician has no interest in showing treasures to others. The text says 'He only cared about getting the magic lamp' for himself. He allows Aladdin to take gems only as a way to get him to retrieve the lamp. Focus on what the text says a character truly cares about.","differentiation_notes":"Targets paragraph 2 focusing on explicit statement of magician's objective - differs from reference which asks about why he uses the uncle disguise as a method","quality_verification":{"homogeneity_check":"all choices are potential goals or purposes for the magician's journey","specificity_check":"all state complete objectives with parallel phrasing","length_check":"A: 9 words, B: 8 words, C: 8 words, D: 8 words - balanced within 10%","semantic_distance_check":"distinct goals: finding family vs teaching vs obtaining lamp vs displaying treasures","single_correct_check":"only C is defensible with direct textual statement of his purpose","diversity_check":"targets paragraph 2 stated objective - different from reference about tactical disguise choice"}},{"question":"How does the ending of this part of the story show a consequence of the magician's impatience?","option_1":"He loses his chance to get the lamp he traveled so far to find","option_2":"He has to climb back down the mountain path by himself","option_3":"He wastes the magical perfumes he brought for the spell","option_4":"He breaks his promise to help Aladdin become a merchant","correct_answer":"A","option_1_explanation":"Correct! Because the magician 'could not wait any longer' and trapped Aladdin with the lamp still in the cave, he fails to get the lamp he came to Persia to find. His impatience causes him to lose what he wanted most. The text shows how acting rashly can backfire. When analyzing consequences, trace how a character's specific trait or action leads to an outcome.","option_2_explanation":"Incorrect. While the magician does have to leave alone, this isn't the main consequence of his impatience. The critical loss is that the lamp stays trapped in the cave, meaning his entire quest fails. Going back down the mountain is a minor detail compared to failing his whole mission. Focus on the most significant result of an action.","option_3_explanation":"Incorrect. The perfumes were already used successfully to open the cave earlier. The consequence of the magician's impatience at the end is that he traps Aladdin before getting the lamp, ruining his whole plan. Don't confuse earlier events with the consequences of later actions.","option_4_explanation":"Incorrect. The magician never truly intended to help Aladdin - that was always a lie. The consequence of his impatience is that he fails to get the lamp, not that he breaks a promise he never meant to keep. This phrase appears right before the magician traps Aladdin in the cave. It reveals that the magician's sole focus on the lamp made him willing to harm Aladdin without hesitation. This shows his selfish and cruel character - he values the object more than the person who helped him. When analyzing character traits, look at what the text says about priorities and how those lead to actions.","option_2_explanation":"Incorrect. The story doesn't suggest the magician fears competition from others. The phrase 'only cared about getting the magic lamp' is used to explain why he trapped Aladdin - it shows single-minded selfishness, not fear. Look for what the phrase directly explains in its context.","option_3_explanation":"Incorrect. While the magician does want the lamp's powers, this phrase appears when explaining why he trapped Aladdin. It reveals his callous character - that his desire for the lamp outweighed any care for Aladdin's safety. Consider what character trait the phrase is meant to emphasize in that moment.","option_4_explanation":"Incorrect. The magician wasn't confused - he was impatient and selfish. The phrase 'only cared about getting the magic lamp' explains his heartless decision to trap Aladdin rather than wait. It shows what matters to him and what doesn't. Look for connections between different parts of the story.","option_2_explanation":"Correct! By telling Aladdin not to touch the treasures, then allowing him to take them after getting the lamp, the magician checks if Aladdin will obey. The text later shows 'Aladdin did exactly what the man asked him to do.' The magician tells Aladdin 'you may take any treasures you want' after getting the lamp, showing he doesn't care about those treasures. The text says 'He only cared about getting the magic lamp.' His instruction was about ensuring obedience.
